title: 115_hr1600
content: The "Veterans Back to Work Act of 2017" is the short title of this Act. It extends and improves the Work Opportunity Tax Credit for veterans. The "Veterans Back to Work Act of 2017" extends and improves the Work Opportunity Tax Credit for veterans by making the credit permanent for veterans and providing a special exemption for certain veterans from employment taxes. The "Veterans Back to Work Act of 2017" extends the Work Opportunity Tax Credit for veterans, providing a special exemption for certain veterans from employment taxes based on specified wage limitations. The "Veterans Back to Work Act of 2017" extends the Work Opportunity Tax Credit for veterans, providing a special exemption for certain veterans from employment taxes based on specified wage limitations. Qualified employers include any employer other than the United States, any State, or any political subdivision thereof, or any instrumentality of the foregoing. The term "specified veteran" is defined for the purposes of this subsection. The term 'specified veteran' refers to an individual who starts working for a qualified employer after a certain date, certifies their veteran status, is not hired to replace another employee unless the previous employee left voluntarily or for cause, and does not fall under certain categories of individuals. The term 'qualified veteran' is defined as per section 51(d)(3) without the need for certification by a designated local agency. 'First-year wages' refer to wages earned in the first year of employment. Coordination with the credit for employment of qualified veterans by tax-exempt organizations is also addressed. The subsection allows qualified employers to elect not to apply it to first-year wages of individuals. Coordination with the work opportunity credit and payroll tax exemption for qualified veterans is addressed, reducing the credit by 7.65 percent of the qualified veteran's wages. The subsection allows qualified employers to elect not to apply it to first-year wages of individuals. Coordination with the work opportunity credit and payroll tax exemption for qualified veterans is addressed, reducing the credit by 7.65 percent of the qualified veteran's wages. Qualified tax-exempt organizations may elect to determine the credit without considering the first-year wages of any individual. The subsection allows qualified employers to elect not to apply it to first-year wages of individuals. Transfers to federal old-age and survivors insurance trust fund are appropriated to offset revenue reductions. Application to railroad retirement taxes is also addressed. The new subsection (d) provides a special exemption for certain veterans, allowing qualified employers to pay first-year compensation at a reduced tax rate equal to the rate under section 3111(b). There is a limitation on the amount of compensation that applies to specified veterans. The new subsection (d) provides a special exemption for certain veterans, allowing qualified employers to pay first-year compensation at a reduced tax rate. The limitation on the amount of compensation for specified veterans is as follows: $125,490 for qualified veterans under section 51(d)(3)(A)(ii)(II), $73,203 for qualified veterans under section 51(d)(3)(A)(iv), $62,745 for qualified veterans under section 51(d)(3)(A)(ii)(I), and $31,373 for any other qualified veteran. The term 'qualified employer' excludes the United States, any State, or any political subdivision thereof, or any instrumentality of the foregoing. The new subsection (d) provides a special exemption for certain veterans, allowing qualified employers to pay first-year compensation at a reduced tax rate. A specified veteran is defined as an individual who starts employment with a qualified employer after the enactment of this subsection, certifies as a qualified veteran, and is not hired to replace another employee unless that employee has left. The term 'qualified veteran' is defined as per section 51(d)(3) without the need for certification by a designated local agency. 'First-year compensation' refers to the compensation for services rendered in the initial year of employment with a qualified employer. During the 1-year period when an individual starts working for an employer, a qualified employer can choose to opt out of this provision. Funds equivalent to the revenue reduction will be appropriated to the Social Security Equivalent Benefit Account under the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974. The amendments made by subsection (a) apply to individuals starting work for the employer after December 31, 2016. The amendments made by subsection (b) apply to amounts paid after the enactment of this Act.
